description:
Home & Studio for Family, Architecture & Movement, part of the
hidden creative side of Clarence Mews. Includes An exhibition of the 'Purbeckian Masque' from Arts University Bournemouth M.Arch students

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The site was originally a Georgian House garden (part of Clapton Square where Lenin visited) after the 2WW it was split off from the house, and had been a car mechanics yard before it was bought in auction in 1998. The Mews is now predominantly residential and the west side is part of the Clapton Square conservation area.

factsheet.heading: Programme & Construction
paragraphs: Construction took place over a series of stages and is still on going, it mixes live and work with a movement and design studios with a family house. The new build space was created around a south facing landscaped courtyard from timber frame blockwork and render, It has a highly insulated skin around the various spaces including the double height studio which faces east. The movement studio with its basket weave Maple dance floor, is Caroline Salem's space, (choreographer and movement director)'where she mentors and develops her and others work.  The design and fabrication of the building was inspired by the work of Walter Segal and Ted Cullinan (his Camden Mews house inc. the birch tree) as well as the modernist Berthold Lubetkin (Architect Ed Frith was his gardener in Bristol in the 1980s) His Bristol Triangle Casino sign will be featured, see photographs.

factsheet.heading: Exhibition
paragraphs: An exhibition in the Dance Studio, the 'Purbeckian Masque', features the Masters work of the 2022 M.Arch students from Arts University Bournemouth where Ed Frith is Course Leader.
